p: Biodiversity is crucial to human well-being as it provides fundamental ecosystem services. At the same time, biodiversity is under threat by human population growth, increased land use, and CO 2 emissions, which are all direct or indirect drivers of climate change [ 1â€“ 3]. One of the regions most threatened by climate change is sub-Saharan Africa [ 4, 5]. This part of Africa is a developing region where deforestation and desertification are of major concern. Within sub-Saharan Africa lies the so-called arid and semi-arid land traversing the savannah belts of the region and making up the Sudano-Sahelian zone (SSZ) [ 6]. This region is socio-economically and ecologically important, but at the same time threatened by climate change, land degradation due to unsustainable agriculture, deforestation, and overgrazing [ 7].
